message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s hypercalcemia, along with his symptoms of weakness, weight loss, and constipation, are concerning for malignancy. The elevated PTHrP level is also suggestive of malignancy-associated hypercalcemia. Chronic kidney disease would not cause such a significant elevation in calcium levels. Hyperparathyroidism would have a much higher PTH level. Hypervitaminosis D can cause hypercalcemia, but the calcitriol level is within normal limits in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypercalcemia, which is a hallmark of malignancy-associated hypercalcemia. The elevated PTH-related protein (PTHrP) also supports this diagnosis. Chronic kidney disease can cause hyperphosphatemia but not hypercalcemia. Hyperparathyroidism and hypervitaminosis D can also cause hypercalcemia but are less likely given the low PTH level and normal calcitriol level, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with hypercalcemia, constipation, unintentional weight loss, and elevated PTHrP levels which suggest a malignancy causing hypercalcemia. Chronic kidney disease will likely cause hypocalcemia, while hyperparathyroidism will have elevated PTH levels. Hypervitaminosis D will have increased calcitriol levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s elevated calcium and PTHrP levels suggest that the most likely cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Chronic kidney disease is more likely to cause hypocalcemia, and hyperparathyroidism and hypervitaminosis D are less likely given the patient’s PTH and calcitriol levels. Additionally, the patient’s unintentional weight loss is also concerning for malignancy.
